Steps.Description: The attacker identifies the vulnerability in the tripcode generation logic of the web application.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker hypothesizes that they can obtain the IP address of the poster by reverse engineering the tripcode generation.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker analyzes code snippets of futaba-ng and identifies the relevant code responsible for tripcode generation.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker successfully reverse engineers the tripcode generation logic.

Steps.Description: The attacker attempts to obtain the IP address of the poster using the reverse engineered tripcode generation logic.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker hypothesizes that they can obtain the IP address of the poster by brute forcing the unknown octets of the IP address.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker iterates over all possible IP addresses and generates the tripcode for each IP address using the reverse engineered tripcode generation logic.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker finds a matching tripcode and obtains the IP address of the poster.

Steps.Description: The attacker accesses the leaked database dump to find the IP address of the poster.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker hypothesizes that the IP address of the poster is stored in the leaked database dump.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker downloads the leaked database dump from the provided URL.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker finds the IP address of the poster in the leaked database dump.

Steps.Description: The attacker identifies the IP address of the poster.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: The attacker hypothesizes that the IP address of the poster is the key information needed to complete the challenge.
StepDetails.Action: The attacker retrieves the IP address either from the successful brute forcing or from the leaked database dump.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker successfully identifies the IP address of the poster.
